Like Timisoara Open navigation drawer Close navigation drawer Settings Location is not active Activate location Cancel %1$s Timisoara European Capital of Culture in 2021 Attractions of Timisoara History of Timisoara Maria Theresia Bastion The Theresia Bastion is the only bastion that still exists in the Timisoara fortress during the period of Banat's affiliation to the Austrian Empire. 
Being the only bastion in Timisoara, it is also known by the Timisoara as Fortress Bastion. The bastion was rehabilitated during 2008-2010. 
Prior to the rehabilitation, it housed commercial areas, restaurants, bars, a nightclub discotheque, a bookstore, two permanent exhibitions of the Banat Museum, the Information and Communication Technology and "Violin - a Lifetime Passion" Ethnography Section of the Banat Village Museum. Timisoreana Brewery The first beer factory in Romania has its origins long ago, being established in the city of Timisoara in the second decade of the eighteenth century. 
The first document attesting to this was given by the administration of the fortress and called for the construction of a beer brew and a brandy boiler. 
Moreover, the same document prohibits the bringing of beer and brandy elsewhere and specifies the obligation of all the villages of Banat to take on certain quantities of these products on a distribution basis. 
This ordinance was dictated by a necessity: the satisfaction of the needs of the Austrian troops left after the liberation from the Ottoman occupation, as well as the substitution of the acute shortage of drinking water, which also led to the development of a series of projects for feeding the Citadel with water through wooden pipes Building a water tower fueled by Bega. 
Beer brewing was built in Palanca Noua, the district that is now called Fabric. Timisoara is the current residence of Timis County, located in the West part of the country, in the Plain of Timis, a plain of two important rivers: Bega and Timiş. 
On the banks of these rivers, a fortified fortress was built - Castrum Temesiense - a well-known fortress in 1212.The fortress developed over time, reaching between 1315-1323 to be the royal residence of King Charles Robert of Anjou. 
Timisoara is first celebrated as Civitas (city) in 1342, and in the 16th century it becomes an important point of resistance against the Ottoman Empire, hence the Crusaders in the Christian War, which ended with the defeat at Nicopole. Also from here starts the military campaign led by Iancu de Hunedoara. 
During the Peasant War (1382-1390, war against feudal exploitation) led by Gheorghe Doja, Timisoara fortress was besieged and several fortified points were occupied. This was for centuries a bastion of Christian civilization, but in 1552 the city was besieged and taught to the Ottomans, and was released from Turkish domination in 1716 by Prince Eugene of Savoya. Thus, he comes under Habsburg rule. 
Under the Habsburg Empire, Timisoara is headed by a military administration, having as governor the Count Mercy Cavalry General. Then Timisoara began an unprecedented flowering process: profound transformations began in the organization of villages and towns, schools, hospitals, churches and monuments were built, and the Transylvania Barracks, with a length of 483 meters, was the longest building Of Europe at that time. 
At that time colonization of Banat villages and towns began with Swabians, Slovaks and Italians, populations that overlapped the already existing population of Romanians, Serbs, Hungarians, Greeks and Jews. 
Thus, Banat becomes a land of tolerance, inter-ethnic understanding, respect and collaboration between people, regardless of nationality or religion.

Museums Banat Museum The Museum of Banat is a museum in Timisoara, Romania, headquartered in Huniade Castle. It was founded in 1872 under the name "The Society for History and Archaeology". 
It hosts the largest collection of archaeological objects Banat. 
The ground floor houses the Parța Neolithic Sanctuary, a unique monument in Europe.The museum includes departments for history, archaeology, ethnography and natural sciences. 
The museum also has a laboratory for conservation and preservation of objects of cultural heritage and history. Banat Village Museum In 1928, Ioachim Miloia, the director of the Museum of Banat (1928-1940), considers the idea of creating an open-air ethnographic museum. 
Banat Village Museum manages to make a thumbnail of Banat villages by building authentic wood, stone and clay houses made after the local model. 
Tourists attracted by the Banat culture can find household items used in the past centuries, can admire the architecture of the houses. 
These, though with 2 or 3 rooms, attract attention with guest rooms, known as "clean stove," big stove" or "good stove”, being the most beautiful furnished and decorated with precious fabrics - towels, rugs, tablecloths once called "masaie". Art Museum The Museum is hosted by the Baroque Palace. The history of the art collection is directly intertwined with the beginnings of the Banat Museum, founded in 1872. 
One of the main exhibitions is the collection of painter Corneliu Baba, with over 80 works signed by master from various periods his artistic creation. 
Timisoara/’s artistic trends of the 1960s to 1980s can be found in the Collection of Contemporary Art. Museum of the communist consumer At the end of 1989, Timisoara became the first city freed from the Communist regime in Romania. 
Shortly after, many Romanians began throwing out items that were used in the household during the Communist era. It was out with the old, in with the new. 
 Museum of the Communist Consumer is a collection of items that Romanians could buy during the “golden age” (as it was called by communist propaganda) that showcases a way of life that was present in every household of Communist Romania.
Squares Traian Square Surrounded by historic buildings, in the center of Fabric district, Traian Square has also been called the Square of Complaint or Kossuth tér and Hauptplatz. 
It was designed by military engineers in 1740, being considered a smaller replica of the Union Square, hosting the daily market and weekly fairs. 
 It has been and is still being used as a square for events. St. Gheorghe Square It is one of the oldest squares in Timisoara and was named after the church worn by St. George, which was transformed into a mosque during the Ottoman occupation. 
On the southern side is the Klapka house, where Georg Klapka, the son of the famous mayor Josef Klapka, was born, who founded the first public lending library in Timisoara and the first in the empire. 
In St. George's Square was launched the first tram on the territory of Romania in July 1869, a premiere for Timisoara. Liberty Square Parade Square "-" Parade Platz "," Prince Eugen Square "-" Jenö herceg tér "or" Freedom Square "-" Freiheitsplatz ", a name acquired during the Revolution of 1848-1849, is undoubtedly the oldest square of Timisoara. 
It is the nucleus from which Timisoara evolved, the first space where people settled and lived continuously on the hearth of the present city. 
Here was also the "Baia Mare", the largest public bath in the city, recently erected by archaeologists, but which is now covered with sand for preservation. 
Liberty shelters some of the oldest buildings in Timisoara: the Garrison Command, the former Chancellery of War - the eastern wing of the Old Town Hall, the Old Town Hall and the Military Casino. Victory Square Located in the heart of Timisoara, Victory Square, the newest square in the city, has a special significance for all Romanians, being the place where the Revolutionaries of Timisoara were gathered and where Timisoara was proclaimed on December 20, 1989, the first free city in Romania. 
The Opera Square, as it was said before the Revolution, was designed in 1870, in the hope that the decision to cancel the military fortress would be obtained. 
It was the main boulevard of the city, from the opera and cathedral to the boulevards called "Corso" for the right side, the place of the high society walk, full of luxury shops and restaurants, and "Surogat" for the left, this being a promenade For young people and workers, but also for soldiers, who had to prove that they are on leave to walk. Union Square Union Square is considered to be the most beautiful market in Timisoara. It hosts some of the most valuable monuments of Timisoara: Baroque Palace, Catholic Cathedral, Serbian Vicarate, Monument of the Holy Trinity. 
Located in the old town, Unirii Square is one of the oldest, not just the most beautiful. It was named in honor of the Romanian troops that entered Timisoara on 3 August 1919 and established the Romanian administration, thus finalizing the union of Banat with Romania. 
 It is also called the "Dome Square" because it hosts the Catholic Dome, built in 1736. It was also called "Hauptplatz", which means the Main Market. 
For three centuries, Union Square was the site of religious events, military parades, and other prestigious political and cultural events. 
It looks as it is today from 1988-1989, the one who "drew it" being the architect Şerban Sturdza.
Parks Central Park The "Anton Scudier" Central Park is one of the oldest parks in Timisoara, founded in 1880 by the general Anton von Scudier. 
In the park there are several monuments of some personalities and the Monument of the Romanian Soldier. 
 The park is equipped with fountains, benches and chess tables. Botanical Park It has an area of nearly 9 ha and is a beautiful dendrological park, which contains a wide variety of tree species. 
In 1995, for the first time, it was declared a scientific reserve in order to protect the local and exotic flora, and Timişoara hopes to be able to declare a protected area one day The Park of Justice The Justice Park, formerly known as the People's Council Park, is located in the center of Timisoara. The name of the park comes from an old building project in the area of the Palace of Justice, abandoned project.In the middle of the park there is the monument of deportees in Baragan during 1951-1956. 
The park was refurbished in 2015, the alleys were rebuilt and an irrigation system mounted. In the park you can find a wide variety of trees and shrubs as well as many flowers: snowflakes, hyacinths, daffodils. In the park is admitted to stay on the grass. The Roses Park The park was established in 1891, along with the Children's Park on the occasion of the Universal Exhibition (Industrial, Commercial and Agrarian), where floral arrangements were made by gardeners Wilhelm Mühle, Franz Niemetz and Beno Agatsy. 
The flowers were admired by Franz Joseph, who visited the exhibition. Landscape landscaping of the park began in 1929 by landscape architects Árpád Mühle, the son of Wilhelm Mühle, and Mihai Demetrovich, the head of the horticulture service of that period. 
The park was designed in English style, with alleys, canopies and rows of roses. During the interwar period the name of the park was Rosarium, and there were over 1200 varieties of roses labeled.Also during this period the theater was arranged in open air. 
In 1944 the park was destroyed after the bombings. After the Second World War, the park was restored, with various outdoor performances taking place. Also in the park there is a sports base, arranged in winter as a skating rink, and in summer as a tennis court. 
In 2012 the park was refurbished. The busts of Wilhelm Mühle (1844-1908), unveiled on 2 August 2013 and Árpád Mühle (1870-1930), unveiled on August 1, 2014, are located near the main entrance of Academician Alexander Borza. Cathedral Park As it's name suggests, the park is close by to the Orthodox Cathedral from Timisoara. More precisely, it's boundaries are the Cathedral, Regele Ferdinand Boulevard, 16th of December 1989 Boulevard and the Bega Canal. 
It is a park where you can stop for a short break to admire the beauty of Timisoara's center. The Civic Park The park has an area of 76,000 square meters. It's on the site, a care took place in the war in Transylvania. This was in 1960 the demolished war plan, a new city center in its place to build. The plan was abandoned and opened Civic Park. Between 1968 and 1971, then the largest building in Timisoara, Continental Hotel, Flower Street The proclamation of Timisoara, a landmark city was here. The Children's Park A precursor of the park was in 1858. Part of Mihai Eminescu Park was finally in a Children's park in 1951. 
It was named the first "Pioneer Park" before the two-year organization. After the revolution in 1989 - Children's Park ("Children's Park"), it was named for the first time, eventually with the suffix "Ion Creanga". 
Between 2006 and 2012 he underwent many modernization works. The reopening took place on June 1, 2012, the International Children's Day. 
The park is divided into zones of 23 age groups. The enchanted forest, the giant land, the liliputani country, the Indian Land, the dark forest or Snow White and the seven dwarves are few. There are regular shows for children and dolls. 
There is a popular carousel, outdoor chess, mountaineering and slide.
Churches and Cathedrals Metropolitan Cathedral of Timisoara The Metropolitan Cathedral of Timisoara is the largest religious building in Timisoara, the cathedral of the Banat Metropolitan Church, dedicated to the "Three Hierarchs". 
It was built between 1936 and 1941 and is a symbol of the city. It is currently the tallest church in Romania (90.5 m) and the tallest Orthodox church in the world outside of Russia (If we consider Russia and Georgia, the Cathedral of Timisoara is the eighth largest in the world) Assumption of the Virgin Mary Church It was built in 1784 on the site of a more wooden church dating back to 1727. At first it was without a tower, only a cross with a globe lay on the roof above the altar. The tower was added in 1836. 
100 years later, in 1894, the current church dedicated to the Assumption of the Virgin was built, according to the plan of the architect Stefan Toth. It has a length of 24.41 m and a width of 7.70 m. The tower is built in baroque style. Saint Catherine Church Saint Catherine Church in Timisoara is a Catholic religious place, a historical monument, built between 1753-1756, on the site of a former mill. Currently, the church serves the Slovak Catholic community in Timisoara. 
Saint Catherine Church is the successor of the medieval Franciscan church. In the crypt of the medieval church was buried in the 13th century Queen Maria de Bytom⁠, the wife of Carol Robert of Anjou. 
According to other sources, Queen Maria would only have died in Timisoara and would have been buried at the Royal Alba. 
The church was turned into a mosque during the Ottoman occupation. Elim Church The current building was founded on November 20, 1988, but its beginnings were noted between 1928-1930. 
At that time, a group of believers from Timisoara (Fabric districts, Ronat and Vii) alternately gathered in their private homes and held the imposing building of today. The birth of Mary the Virgin Church It was founded in 1921 following the steps taken by the faithful worshipers Iacob Marian and Emanoil Ungurianu. 
The parish church, dedicated to the Nativity of the Mother of God, was built between 1932 and 1936 and was sanctified on September 8, 1936, the parish priest being Ioan Imbroane. 
The worship site re-creates the traditional monastery style, with a special bell tower, the interior being inspired by the famous Saint Sofia in Constantinople. 
The mural painting was performed by Professor Catul Bogdan and Dr. Ioachim Miloia, and later was restored by Anastasie Demian and Victor Jurca, the iconostasis, the chandelier and the furniture being carved by Stefan Gajo and Stefan Novac. Millennium Cathedral The church project was developed by the architect YBL LAJOS and the construction was carried out by the constructor KREMER JÓZSEF. The foundation stone was deposited on October 4, 1896. The church was consecrated on 13 October 1901. 
 The church is built in neo-roman style and is covered from the outside with raw brick. The walls of the church are 1-3.64 m thick. Three statues of natural size are placed above the gate: the apostles Peter and Paul, and in the middle the Christ Savior with the cross. 
The main dimensions of the church: 
Length measured outside: 71.12m. 
The inner surface of the church is 1170.15m², where 48 banks are located. Roman Catholic Cathedral of Saint George Roman Catholic Dome is the cathedral of the Roman Catholic Episcopate of Timisoara and one of the city's emblematic monuments. 
The edifice is dedicated to St. George and was built between 1736 and 1774. The turrets have a low height, determined by the proximity of the fortress wall. 
The interior is rich and sumptuous, noting the 9 altars decorated in Baroque and Rococo style, carved by Viennese Johan Müller, decorated with old icons, the organ built by Carl Leopold Wegenstein in 1908, but also the oak doors decorated with pure nickel grids . 
The Roman Catholic Dome (the Roman Catholic Cathedral) is considered to be the most unitary and representative Baroque building of Timisoara and one of the most valuable in Banat.
